replies.commentText: "Whataboutism (also known as Whataboutery) is a red >herring version of the classic tu quoque logical fallacy - sometimes implementing the balance fallacy as well - which is employed as a propaganda technique. It is used as a diversionary tactic to shift the focus off of an issue and avoid having to directly address it. This technique works by twisting criticism back onto the critic and in doing so revealing the original critic's hypocrisy. The usual syntax is "What about...?" followed by an issue on the opponent's side which is vaguely, if at all, related to the original issue. A n old favorite of the Soviet Union, the strategy was originally used in the form of "And at your place, they ha ng black people." In recent years, whataboutism made a comeback in Vladimir Putin's Russia (since the Russians seemingly learned all the wrong lessons from the Cold War), and has also seen a rise in usage by Donald Trump and his support base. Simply put, whataboutism refers to the bringing up of one issue in order to distract from the discussion of another."

Cenk, this is aimed directly at you as one of the best known non--politician leaders of the progressive movement. I have had a problem with you ever since I started watching TYT, although I watched you on MSNBC for a long time without ever seeing this problem. I am sure it existed them, I simply didn't notice it. We are all human, and as such, are imperfect and in one way or another, all problems that can exist in humans exists in every one of us. Racism, sexism and every other "ism" that exists can be found in every one of us to some extent. Around the time that I quit watching MSNBC (before you left that network) I was beginning to teach using this "mantra" as a guiding principle: "If you cannot be honest with yourself you cannot be honest with anyone else." That kind of self-honesty is largely lacking from both you and Ana, and as a result from the entire organization and its followers. I find it very grating when you or Ana say, "But we are progressives so we don't do that." All to often that statement either follows or is followed by some act or statement of blindness where you do just that, but not quite so openly. Unfortunately, because of the claim made that we do not do that, the act or statement is considerably MORE egregious than what the Repelicans do and say so openly. Yes , Sexism, along wi th racism and ageism (something well demonstrated among the Young Turks this past week by Emma and John) are much worse that any of us realize, but it is because we refuse to recognize and acknowledge those traits in ourselves. Emma is very defini tely ageist. Don't bother denying it. The comment she made is true, but she made it only about OLD right-wingers and not right-wingers in general, including many who are younger than her. J ohn is ageist too. He did not notice Emma's remark and how offensive it was, and allowed it to go without comment. You lost some listeners over that if the comments are to be believed. Y et such ageism is not the defining characteristic of either Emma or John, and it is unfortunate that this gaffe has diminished your organization agai nst this age group. "Unless we can be honest with ourselves," means that we much ALWAYS look at ourselves, both individually and as a group (tribe) and say, "What am I doing or saying that shows this is a problem in me," and, "What is the group to which I belong doing or saying that proves it is a problem in us." Until we do this and address the problem within rather than deny it, hide it, bury it deep within, we neither have the moral right to address it in anyone else, nor will we ever have any understanding as to just how serious the problem really is. Maybe you don't have a pro blem with sexism o r racism or ageism or any other ism because of good education at an early age or having learned otherwise from honest observations later in life. After all, you are a repentant repelican, as I am. But just because you have overcome these sins does not mean they are totally eradicated from your life and does not mean the rest of your group had had that epiphany. BECAUSE you have not been honest with yourself about any of those "buts" you have not been really honest about anything else or with anyone else. You are on the right track with this new understanding. Keep on keeping on. That is what really makes us "progressive" Myron

Women are generally smaller than men , so overall women will have a slightly smaller brain . 
But brain power has much more to do with how large certain sections of the brain are compared to the next individual.

The brain is not unlike a muscle, as it will increase or decrease in size and active in certain sections, due positive or negative influences,and this will determine the level of intelligence for the individual.

A larger more active amygdala is often the result of negative influences the individual has been exposed to.
With negative influences the amygdala will increase in size and activity, where the individual will have too much fear and aggression fight or flight with a larger more active amygdala section of the brain.

But it's also a double whammy effect by having insufficient capacity to process critical thought with a smaller less active anterior cingulate cortex.
The ACC is the more recently developed section of the brain in human evolution, and is also connected to the rest of the brain, making the ACC critical for processing critical thought. 

While other individuals will have the opposite situation. 
A smaller less active amygdala, and larger more active anterior cingulate cortex.

There is no difference between men and women . And everyone is different with a different level of development.

replies.commentText: If you're not over 50, you won't get it, but let me try to explain something. Growing up Elizabeth Warren did not grow up with computers and internet, DNA tests, or even a push button phone. You got all your news from news papers and if you weren't poverty stricken (which Warren was) you might have been lucky enough to watch the local news at six (in black and white).Kids used books called encyclopedias to look up information at a library. In other words, info was very difficult to come by. In those days we passed on family information by word of mouth (a habit formed by thousands of years of practice) over coffee at the kitchen table, or shelling beans on the porch. If your parents or grandparents said it, then it was true. That was the only way TO do it. You learn something young and it becomes ingrained in you. It may never have occurred to her to doubt it. What kind of proof did the colleges even ask for? To assume that when someone is wrong about something, they are liars, is harsh and unrealistic. You wouldn't want to live that way. No one should have to.

I never pretended to be a Native, and and I sure didn't put it on a professional certificate in a time and place when token diversity hires with as little diversity as possible was fashionable and lucrative. But you want to contend that she's ok because she "didn't know," right? Well she hadn't a damned thing to say of any value on any Native issue from the day she claimed she was practicing law as a Native in the 70s til she avoided the hell out of Standing Rock (but found plenty of time to kiss Hillary's ass). @hellcat1988 
If you take a poll of 100 progressives, with the question;


"If most positions of political power were held by women instead of men, how would the state of the world be?
1) worse
2) the same
3) better"


I'm quite confident that you'd get far more responses that say "better" than "worse".
I'm sure that a decent number of progressives would be very certain that things would be better.

@Light And Shadow And with your assumptions, you're already using your bias to influence the conversation in your favor.  Saying most, but not all leaves a HELL of a lot of room for personal interpretation on behalf of the person being polled to figure out just how much "most" would mean. 

Second, making the assumption that you know what the results would be without actually doing the study makes clear that you've already formed an opinion of what the data would show, rather than actually letting the data speak for itself.  I would say that it's you forming a hypothesis, but I'm guessing you don't plan to actually conduct the study under reasonable scientific conditions.
Third, by leaving out any ambiguity through asking how the people FEEL the world would be in your scenario, you're asking them to attempt to factually answer a question that there is no reasonable data to infer from; as that situation has never actually been even close to a reality.
It's all just bad science aimed at showing a perceived bias that may or may not exist based on an extremely limited data set.


Ignoring all that, I doubt the majority would answer "better."  More likely the majority would answer "same" but you would ignore that set and only focus on the people who answered "worse" or "better" to fit your narrative.  Again, crap science.

commentThread.commentText: With another 10 years of evolution on the topic of sexism, Cenk might realize that the sexism is towards treating men as agents and women as objects. Which works in men's favor for positive, and works in women's favor for negative things. Eg, the same dynamic of "Men are in X position because of their own decisions" works against men in the criminal justice system. You will virtually never see progressives saying "The facts show that white men are in more danger of being killed by the police tha n black women, becau se gender is an even bigger factor t han race".

replies.commentText: So you're saying Black women SHOULD be more in danger of being killed by police than white men?
@Noni R  That is obviously not what he said. He is just pointing out that sexism isn't just always positive for men and negative for women. The topic is more complex than that.

@Noni R I'd find political discourse more satisfying if it was more fact based. People generally view sexism as analogous to racism/civil rights/one sided power dynamics. Instead I think it is more analogous to the dynamics between military and civilians, where there is a tacit agreement to a complex set of interdependent relationships where both bimodal groups both experience various forms of power and powerlessness. The whole paradigm of how sexism is generally viewed, is insufficient. It can't get the job done by itself because it is too narrow. Activists usually focus on the "black" part of black male in terms of systemic discrimination in the criminal justice system. The facts suggest that the "male" part is much more relevant in terms of systemic injustice. Society can ignore men's issues for a while, but they can't ignore them forever, because eventually a bunch of marginalized men get together and flip the monopoly board by voting in Trump. Cenk is representing one small piece of the truth, in a fragmented mess, where lots of different small pieces of truth are represented by different people. Most of them not realizing that it's a zigsaw puzzle, where a lot of different pieces are needed.
@Philipp I was only commenting on the last sentence because it sounds awful. I know that wasn't the point of the statement

@Noni R Yeah, that's kinda my point. It sounds so awful, because it is so jarring to think of men as being discriminated against in some significant ways. "Around police, men have it worse than black people?" That just fries progressive circuits. It does not compute. The idea that white men need more help than black women, is so confusing, that it gets turned into "So you mean we should achieve parity by making lives worse fo r black women?" No, the (idealistic) point is to improve all people's lives based on need, and in terms of police violence, the statistics suggest white men have more need th an black women.
